summary: the patient was from guangzhou, the capital of the southern province of Guangdong. he was hospitalized on February 26 and died on March 2. he visited 9 food markets that had live birds. 12 goose 5 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 3 1 3 1 0 0 3 1 6 4 20 7 Pigeon 15 0 20 3 10 2 0 0 0 0 0 15 2 10 1 70 5 140 13 Partridge 30 0 45 0 30 1 0 0 0 0 0 0 10 1 20 2 135 4 Quail 80 0 110 0 60 0 0 0 0 0 0 positive PCR results were confirmed by sequencing. none of 94 anal swabs from live birds tested positive for HPAI H5N1. serum samples were obtained from 110 of 121 poultry purveyors working at the live bird food markets. one of 110 serum samples was positive (titer 320) by hemagglutination-inhibition assay with turkey erythrocytes. five patients with H5N1 infection with no history of exposure to diseased or dead birds before the onset of avian influenza have been reported in the People's Republic of China. the first patient was a 41-year-old woman from Fuzhou, the capital of Fujian Province. the introduction of H5N1 virus from healthy poultry may be occurring where no outbreaks in healthy flocks have been observed. the culture preference of eating freshly slaughtered birds is not unique to the People's Republic of China; it is common in other Asian countries.
